linkTarget.anchoringText: The Greater Burgan field (Fig. 1), discovered in 1938, is located in southeast Kuwait and comprises the Magwa, Ahmadi, and Burgan fields, constituting the largest known siliciclastic oil reservoir on Earth. The size of the field, 20-km wide and 37.5-km length, provides an estimate of its large extension. The three main formations of Wara, Burgan, and Mauddud have a global total thickness of 1,500 ft with complex behaviors resulting from fluvial/tidal depositional settings.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Greater Burgan field map ( Sorkhabi 2012 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Sorkhabi, 2012
S. Sorkhabi
2012. The Great Burgan Field, Kuwait . GeoExPro 9 (1): 42 46 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Formation-tester measurements were used to estimate relative permeability based on the workflow depicted in Fig. 2. The inputs of this workflow were pressure transient measurements from miniDSTs in oil, water, transition zones, and water saturation logs. The followings steps are described in Fig. 2:

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Estimation of relative permeability curves with integration of formation tester and well logs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimation of relative permeability curves with integration of formation tester and well logs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The effective permeabilities of oil and water multiplied by thickness (ko*h and kw*h) are divided by the absolute permeability multiplied by thickness (kabs*h), which provides the relative permeability values. Fig. 3 illustrates the steps for this part.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Determining the endpoints of relative permeability curves from formation-tester measurements.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Determining the endpoints of relative permeability curves from formation-tester measurements.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To determine the curvature of relative permeability, the effective permeabilities of oil and water multiplied by pay zone thickness are measured in the transition zone. Fig. 4 shows how to obtain relative permeability of oil and water in the transition zone. Increasing the number of miniDSTs in the transition zone adds confidence to the estimated curvature.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Estimation of relative permeabilities from miniDST measurements in the transition zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimation of relative permeabilities from miniDST measurements in the transition zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A formation tester with a simple circular probe was used to perform the miniDST because of the large mobility expected in the reservoir. Based on the logs, four points were selected for fluid pumpout; from top, the first point was at irreducible water saturation; second and third points were in the transition zone; and the last point was in the free water zone. Table 1 summarizes the wireline-conveyed formation tester pumpout points along with their purpose and associated water saturation. Fig. 5 shows the pumpout points along with formation evaluation log data and interpretation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Pumpout stations are depicted by black dots on the fourth track. First track shows GR, SP, caliper, and bit size. Second track shows density, neutron, PE, and correction applied on the density log. Third track is the array of resistivities. Last track shows the water and hydrocarbon volumes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pumpout stations are depicted by black dots on the fourth track. First track shows GR, SP, caliper, and bit size. Second track shows density, neutron, PE, and correction applied on the density log. Third track is the array of resistivities. Last track shows the water and hydrocarbon volumes.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A total of 150 L was pumped during this drawdown test. Fig. 6 shows the log-log, semilog, and the simulation match along with the results of the miniDST. The absolute permeability multiplied by thickness, kh, was determined to be 68,773 md/ft.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST at the water zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST at the water zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A total of 130 L was pumped. Fig. 7 shows the log-log, semilog, and the simulation match along with the results of the miniDST. The effective permeability to oil times thickness, koh, was determined to be 58,617 md/ft.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST at the oil zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST at the oil zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 8 shows the log-log, semilog, and the simulation match along with the results of the miniDST. Effective permeability to oil times thickness, ko*h, was determined to be 54,806 md/ft, and the effective permeability to water times thickness, kw*h, was determined to be 2,234.4 md/ft. Similarly, another pumpout was performed in the transition zone about 20 ft below the third pumpout depth. Based on the well logs, the Sw at this point was estimated at 65.6%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST for pumpout depth 3 in the transition zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST for pumpout depth 3 in the transition zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 9 shows the log-log, semilog, and the simulation match along with the results of the miniDST. Effective permeability to oil times thickness, ko*h, was determined to be 9,082.5 md/ft, and the effective permeability to water times thickness, kw*h, was determined to be 21,735 md/ft.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST for the pumpout depth 4 in the transition zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log-log, semilog, and simulation match, and the analysis results for miniDST for the pumpout depth 4 in the transition zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The downhole effective permeability estimation was described in detail. After following the workflow, the effective permeability data obtained from the miniDST analyses was divided by the absolute permeability to yield the relative permeability curves (Fig. 10). The curve connecting the points is a best-fit curve obtained by minimizing the fit error. The relative permeability of Fig. 10 shows a mixed to water-wet reservoir rock for the Burgan middle sand.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Relative permeability obtained from miniDST analysis.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative permeability obtained from miniDST analysis.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The FWL was at 5,269.5 ft, and the OWC was at 4,993.5 ft. Water saturations obtained from the well logs at different depths were plotted in Fig. 11 versus the oil height above the FWL.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: The oil height above the FWL curve vs. water saturation, OWC = 4,993.5 ft and FWL = 5,269.5 ft.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The oil height above the FWL curve vs. water saturation, OWC = 4,993.5 ft and FWL = 5,269.5 ft.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water and oil densities at each depth plus the height above the FWL of Fig. 11 were used to generate the capillary pressure curve from Eq. 3 (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Capillary pressure curve obtained from the density measurements where Pd = 38.22 psi.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Capillary pressure curve obtained from the density measurements where Pd = 38.22 psi.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To overcome the uncertainty in saturation of each tested depth, resistivity, dielectric, and NMR logs were run to estimate fluid saturation separately. Table 2 shows the minimum and maximum saturation values chosen based on these measurements, and Fig. 13 shows the uncertainty envelope generated for the relative permeability curves. The results were in line with pulsed neutron capture (PNC) saturation logs over the years.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Uncertainty bounds for relative permeability based on saturation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Uncertainty bounds for relative permeability based on saturation.
